entry.title: Combined summary - Rebatable fees & incentive-safe fee markets
entry.summary: The Bitcoin network's fee model has been a topic of discussion on various platforms. One proposal is to set a maximum fee rate calculated as a filter over past block rates to prevent "outlier behavior." However, concerns were raised that miners might limit the number of transactions in a block to capture the highest fees, which could lead to network congestion.Another proposal suggests moving to a "pay lowest winning bid" model, which would eliminate the need for fee estimate mechanisms and adjust transaction fees. The Monopolistic Price Mechanism proposed in the RSOP paper was also debated, with concerns about its real-world implications for fee selection UX. Additionally, a user on a Bitcoin forum raised concerns about the current mining scheme incentivizing miners to limit the amount of transactions in a block. There are ongoing discussions around improving efficiency and fairness in the Bitcoin network. The Bitcoin-dev mailing list has been discussing the fee market and proposed solutions for improving it. One proposal suggests moving to a "pay lowest winning bid" model, where all transactions pay only the smallest fee rate paid by any transaction in the block. Another proposal is for a new feature called "rebateable fees," which would allow transactions to specify an implicit fee as well as one or more explicit rebateable fees. However, some members of the mailing list have expressed doubts about the real-world implications of these proposals.There are also concerns about the potential for miners to limit the number of transactions in a block to capture the maximum fee, which could lead to network congestion. A proposed fix to the fee model that is not easily broken by paying the miner out of band was discussed, but there were concerns that it could also lead to centralization. Overall, the discussion highlights the need for further exploration and optimization of the Bitcoin network's fee structure and incentives for miners.Time sensitivity is an important factor to consider, as the fee users are willing to pay often changes over time. The RBF loop was discussed as a possibility for adjusting fees based on time sensitivity. Reliability-based-price-discrimination might also allow higher mining revenue via having txes with differing fee rates in the same block. The Bitcoin community has been discussing various proposals to fix the current fee model. One proposal suggests removing all transactions with fees below 1 BTC, while another proposes a "pay lowest winning bid" model where all transactions pay only the smallest fee rate paid by any transaction in the block. However, there are concerns that such models could lead to centralization and reduce visibility of fees. Another proposed fix involves rebateable fees, which would allow transactions to specify an implicit fee as well as one or more explicit rebateable fees. While this proposal has potential benefits, there are questions about its implementation and game-theoretic compatibility.Further discussions have focused on preventing "outlier behavior" in mining, where a user pays high fees every ten minutes to avoid lower fee-paying transactions reducing the fees earned. Proposed solutions include a maximum fee rate calculated as a filter over past block rates or establishing a marginal fee rate and allowing for rebateable fees to contribute towards meeting the remaining marginal fee requirement. However, there are concerns that these solutions may incentivize miners to limit the number of transactions in a block to capture the maximum fee.In addition, there are debates about the real-world implications of a fee market in which users can pay less if they overpay and whether a PI controller on the maximum size could recover lost space in single blocks with bogon fee transactions without affecting medium timescale total. Practical reasons such as budgeting communications and storage capacity for nodes make it impossible to assume that there is no limit. Overall, the Bitcoin community continues to explore and optimize the fee structure and incentives for miners.
